poem.author: Ian Pople
poem.title: Rain
verses: A lexicon of words that were not </br> said in childhood, and all of those </br> that were, were said beside
an upturned boat, lapped </br> planking of the creosoted shed,</br> were said into the wind on </br> tussocky ground, by farm-rust vehicles.

The buildings I could not complete </br> without my father’s help, the wind </br> in which I was at sea. Rain blooming </br> in August that moved the land </br> and over land toward the autumn, </br> sliding through the gates of summer, </br> feeling for the bone inside the wrist.
